Glossary

A

Access Control Database (ACDB)
An encrypted file that defines the users who are authorized to perform actions on projects and defines the actions that users can perform. Access control databases can be associated with both project databases and projects. You can define user IDs, passwords, user expiration dates, groups of users (access list groups), and privileges assigned to the users in access control databases. Only user IDs are required.

Access List
An attribute of an archive that defines the users and access list groups authorized to perform operations on the archive. The users and groups in the access list must be defined in the access control database.

Access List Group
A group of users defined in an access control database that enables the administrator to control security collectively rather than individually. Instead of assigning privileges to individual users or adding individual users to access lists, the administrator can specify one group name that represents multiple users. Access list groups are used for security only if access lists are used.

Archive
A Version Manager file that stores the evolutionary history of a versioned file. The history of a versioned file includes descriptions of changes, who made them, and when they were made. There is one archive for each versioned file. Archives also contain version label and promotion group information.

B

Baselining
The process of creating a snapshot of an existing project at a specific point in its development. To create a baseline, you copy an entire project into a new project based on a version label, promotion group, or revision number. The baselined project does not contain revision history; therefore, any revision that does not meet the version label, promotion group, or revision number criteria is not copied into the baselined project. Note that you cannot baseline when copying Version Manager 5.3/6.0 projects and project roots.

Branch
A separate line of development consisting of one or more revisions that diverge from a revision on the trunk or on another branch. Branching lets you develop alternate variations of a file in parallel with the continued development of the revision from which it was branched. Version Manager automatically assigns revision numbers sequentially to branch revisions in the format of 1.0.1.0.

C

Configuration Options
Settings that control how Version Manager operates while a project database or project is open and active. By default, a project inherits the project configuration settings that are defined for its project database.

D

Default Version
Identifies the revision to operate on (for example, the revision to check out). Typically, the default version is the latest revision of a versioned file. However, the default version can be defined in a workspace or a project database's or project's configuration file to be a specific version label, promotion group, or revision number.

Delta
A binary record containing the differences between a revision and its immediate ancestor. Version Manager stores deltas in the versioned file's archive.

E

Event Trigger
An administrator-specified program that is executed when a specified Version Manager event occurs. Version Manager supports the following as event triggers: stand-alone Windows (.EXE) and UNIX executable programs, Windows batch scripts, Windows program information files, and UNIX shell scripts.

Events
An event is a particular action that occurs during Version Manager processing (such as checking in a file), the click of a user-defined tool bar icon, and the selection of a user-defined menu item. Event triggers that are defined are executed when a specified Version Manager event occurs.

F

Folder
Folders provide a method of organizing versioned files within a project. Folders are only available in Version Manager 5.3/6.0 projects. In the current release of Version Manager, folders have been replaced by subprojects, which you can create in other projects in order to replicate the exact hierarchy of your working directories.

M

Master Configuration File
A master configuration file contains configuration options (settings that control how Version Manager operates) for a project database and all of its projects. Version Manager automatically creates a master configuration file for each project database that is created. A master configuration file lets you standardize how Version Manager operates by identifying options that cannot be reset by other configuration files.

Master Project
Master projects are used only in Version Manager 5.3 project roots. For each 5.3 project root, there is one master project. The master project defines how Version Manager operates on all of the projects within the project root. By default, projects inherit the configuration options of the master project within the project root. However, by setting the allow/disallow configuration options in the master project, an administrator can control whether or not a user can modify the configuration settings a project inherits from the master project. The current release of Version Manager does not use master projects because the project database (known as project root in Version Manager 5.3/6.0) can be configured, and these settings are then inherited by the projects within the project database.

Merging
Comparing the changes contained in two revisions with a common ancestor and then combining the changes they represent into a single new revision.

P

Parallel Development
Development that continues separate from the main line of development. Typically this occurs when you are making changes, such as bug fixes, that you don't want to immediately affect the main line of development, or when you are beginning a new version of a software product. Parallel development usually requires branching off the main trunk of a versioned file.

Privilege
A privilege enables a Version Manager action. Privileges are specified in the access control database to grant users permission to use the action. For example, GetTip is the privilege of letting users check out tip revisions from archives.

Project
Logical groupings of subprojects and versioned files. Although a project database defines configuration options for each project contained within it, you can configure each project individually.

Project Database
A hierarchical collection of projects, subprojects, and versioned files. A project database defines the archive location for the projects it contains and a common configuration for all projects and subprojects contained within it. Version Manager users are defined for each project database.

Promotion
The process of moving revisions forward from one stage of a development lifecycle to the next stage.

Promotion Group
A phase of a promotion model, representing a milestone in the application development cycle. Some examples of typical promotion groups include Development, Quality Assurance, and Production.

Promotion Model
A hierarchy of promotion groups representing milestones in a development cycle. A promotion model enforces active development work to be associated with the lowest-level group in the promotion model (for example, the Development promotion group). When you create a promotion model, Version Manager associates revisions with the promotion groups in the model. You can then perform operations based on promotion groups, in the same manner as version labels. A User's privileges can be restricted by promotion group.

R

Reference Directory
Directory where Version Manager can maintain a copy of the latest revision of each versioned file in a project. Reference directories are useful for maintaining copies of the latest versions for printing, compilation, browsing, etc. Reference directories are defined through a configuration option.

Revision
An instance of a versioned file that can be re-created. Revisions are stored in archives. When you check in a workfile, the changes made to the workfile are stored as a revision in an archive. When you check out a revision, Version Manager creates a workfile in the specified workfile location.

Revision History
A record of the changes made over time to a particular versioned file.

Revision Number
A number automatically assigned by Version Manager to each revision of a versioned file. Each line of development is numbered sequentially. Version Manager assigns trunk revisions revision numbers in the format of 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, 2.1, etc. Branch revisions are automatically assigned revision numbers in the format of 1.0.1.0, 1.0.2.0, etc.

Root Workspace
The default public workspace created when a project database is created. Each project database has one Root Workspace from which all other workspaces are derived. The settings that are initially defined in the Root Workspace are: the workfile location you set for the project database, the default revision to use for actions if the master configuration file has the default revision defined, and automatic branching if the master configuration file has automatic branching set up.

S

Software Configuration Management (SCM)
The process of organizing and managing changes to the components of your software development efforts.

T

Tip Revision
The latest revision on a trunk or branch.

Trunk
The primary set of revisions of a versioned file. Branches originate from a versioned file's trunk or from another branch. Version Manager automatically assigns revision numbers sequentially to trunk revisions in the format of 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, etc.

V

Version Control
The process of managing and maintaining multiple revisions of the same versioned file in an archive.

Version Label
A label, or tag, used to identify a specific revision of a versioned file. Version labels can be used to efficiently check out and promote revisions that belong together, such as all of the revisions that were used to create a beta version of an application.

Versioned File
A file and its revisions under source control. A versioned file maintains information about the name and location of the archive where the revisions are physically stored, thus eliminating the need to specify this information each time you access a revision of the versioned file.

W

Workfile
Any file that you are checking in to Version Manager to create a new revision or archive. When you check out a revision, Version Manager stores it as a workfile in the specified workfile location.

Workfile Location
The working directory to which you check out revisions and from which you check in workfiles. Workfile locations are stored with workspace settings. You can define workfile locations for project databases, projects, and versioned files.

Workspace
A collection of work settings defined for a project database, which includes the work settings for all of the projects and versioned files contained within the project database. These work settings include workfile location, default version, base version, and branch version.
